<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
1 A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 121, 411, 138]]<|/det|>
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 152, 643, 375]]<|/det|>

(a) The student suspends a mass \(m=100 \mathrm{~g}\) from the spring.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 918, 471]]<|/det|>
She measures, and records in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 918, 516]]<|/det|>
Describe two techniques for measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 670, 134, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

Her readings are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 120, 539, 135]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[356, 152, 644, 297]]<|/det|>

The line might not go through the origin. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 384, 801, 813]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 870, 144, 887]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 868, 757, 887]]<|/det|> (c) Use your graph to determine the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring with no load on it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 898, 918, 918]]<|/det|>

<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 895, 107]]<|/det|>
(e) Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus. One student records the mass as 132.6 g . The other student records the mass as 130 g .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 121, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 170, 918, 186]]<|/det|>
statement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 201, 918, 216]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 682, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 459, 122]]<|/det|>
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 611, 152]]<|/det|>
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 167, 572, 183]]<|/det|>
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 197, 915, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 518, 533, 535]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 551, 144, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 551, 185, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 551, 752, 567]]<|/det|>
(a) (i) Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 581, 580, 598]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}=\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 188, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 612, 915, 644]]<|/det|>
(ii) Describe one technique used to ensure that the room temperature reading is as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|> (b) The student pours \(200 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t=0\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 120, 802, 138]]<|/det|> He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 152, 555, 170]]<|/det|> The student repeats the procedure for beaker B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 183, 738, 201]]<|/det|> It is important that the temperatures are recorded at exactly every 30 s. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 214, 747, 231]]<|/det|> Describe a technique which will make it easier for the student to do that. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 336, 540, 352]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[420, 368, 725, 596]]<|/det|>
beaker A with insulationbeaker B without insulation
\(t / s\)\(\theta /^{\circ}C\)\(\theta /^{\circ}C\)
092.593.0
3090.590.5
6089.088.5
9087.587.0
12086.085.5
15085.084.0
18085.583.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 611, 144, 627]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 610, 918, 643]]<|/det|> (c) Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 185, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 918, 108]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 119, 556, 151]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{1}=\frac{\theta_{0}-\theta_{90}}{T}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 160, 918, 192]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{0}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t=0\) and \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 208, 330, 223]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 266, 918, 285]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{1}=

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 300, 188, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 298, 918, 331]]<|/det|>
(ii) Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 343, 567, 375]]<|/det|>
\[
x_{2}=\frac{\theta_{90}-\theta_{180}}{T}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 384, 918, 416]]<|/det|>
where \(T=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t=90 \mathrm{~s}\) and \(t=180 \mathrm{~s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 432, 330, 447]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 491, 918, 510]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{2}=

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 523, 144, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 523, 918, 555]]<|/det|>
(e) A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t=0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 570, 785, 587]]<|/det|>
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 76, 185, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(f) (i) A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 120, 641, 138]]<|/det|>
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 214, 188, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 214, 920, 245]]<|/det|>
(ii) Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 667, 91]]<|/det|>
3 A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 598, 123]]<|/det|>
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 135, 875, 775]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 790, 532, 808]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 822, 144, 839]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 822, 918, 854]]<|/det|>
(a) The student places a transparent block \(A B C D\) near the centre of the ray-trace sheet as indicated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 870, 185, 887]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 868, 918, 900]]<|/det|>
(i) Draw a normal to point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 75, 190, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 74, 590, 91]]<|/det|>
(ii) The student draws line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 89, 770, 107]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 3.1, measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the lines \(\mathbf{LN}\) and \(\mathbf{EN}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 104, 556, 122]]<|/det|>
An acute angle is an angle of less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[693, 151, 780, 168]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta =\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 184, 144, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 183, 740, 201]]<|/det|>
(b) The student places two pins \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) on line \(\mathbf{EN}\) as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 215, 185, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 214, 568, 231]]<|/det|>
(i) Measure distance \(d\) between pins \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[662, 243, 880, 260]]<|/det|>
<form>\(d =\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 275, 190, 292]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 275, 853, 307]]<|/det|>
(ii) State whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Explain your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 322, 920, 339]]<|/det|>
statement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 352, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
explanation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 415, 144, 431]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 414, 664, 431]]<|/det|>
(c) The student views the images of \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) through the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 428, 918, 460]]<|/det|>
He places two pins \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\) so that pins \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\) and the images of \(\mathbf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{2}\) all appear exactly one behind the other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 475, 648, 492]]<|/det|>
Draw a line through \(\mathbf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathbf{P}_{4}\). Extend this line to meet \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 507, 918, 537]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line meets \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{F}\). Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{G}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 553, 590, 570]]<|/det|>
Extend line \(\mathbf{EN}\) to approximately 5 cm below line \(\mathbf{CD}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 568, 918, 600]]<|/det|>
Label the point at which this line crosses \(\mathbf{CD}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{H}\). Label the lower end of this line with the letter \(\mathbf{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 631, 144, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 631, 185, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 631, 640, 648]]<|/det|>
(d) (i) Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{GF}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 662, 880, 679]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 693, 640, 710]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between lines \(\mathbf{CD}\) and \(\mathbf{JH}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[714, 723, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\beta =\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 770, 144, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 770, 686, 787]]<|/det|>
(ii) A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 801, 918, 832]]<|/det|>
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 847, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
statement

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 878, 920, 894]]<|/det|>
justification

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 885, 91]]<|/det|>
(e) Describe two techniques to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 245, 144, 262]]<|/det|>
<label>(f)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 245, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
(f) Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 502, 91]]<|/det|>
4 A student investigates the resistance of a wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 918, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 140, 551, 170]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R=\frac{V}{I}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 180, 833, 197]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 212, 405, 228]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 320, 257]]<|/det|>
- a selection of wires

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 355, 273]]<|/det|>
- a variable power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 260, 288]]<|/det|>
- an ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 257, 304]]<|/det|>
- a voltmeter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 225, 336]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 460, 366]]<|/det|>
- list any additional apparatus needed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 918, 413]]<|/det|>
- complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 428, 918, 459]]<|/det|>
- explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 475, 489, 490]]<|/det|>
- state the key variables to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 505, 918, 537]]<|/det|>
- draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 604, 567]]<|/det|>
- explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 580, 675, 800]]<|/det|>

This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 914, 917, 937]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of Cambridge Assessment. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is a department of the University of Cambridge.
